journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Multi-objective trade-off analysis of an integrated cold gas propulsion system

article-meta.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Afshin Banazadeh, Center of Excellence in Aerospace Systems, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran 1136511155, Iran. Email: banazadeh@sharif.ir

abstract.p: The overall design of cold gas propulsion systems is pretty complicated when considering the mission requirements, operating constraints and functional limitations imposed by the mechanical components. To address this complication, a precise design process is proposed, which attempts to optimize the cost of operation as well as to minimize the waste volume and weight by using multi-objective trade-off analysis. This analysis is based on a set of ordinary differential equations that are solved iteratively to describe the optimal behavior of the system. Therefore, a numerical code is being developed to give insight on the design sensitivity with respect to uncertainties on the design variables. Consequently, the most favorite operating media, nozzle inlet pressure and tank charging pressure are determined. Moreover, the advantages of electric heater for the storage tank are studied for a specified mission. A three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics analysis is employed to accurately simulate the flow conditions inside the nozzle. The accuracy of the simulation is verified by correlation with experimental results obtained from a non-vacuum test set-up. The experimental results have revealed acceptable performance and agreement with the simulation, within 7% in error.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
In the 1960s, cold gas propulsion systems were preferred as standard reaction control mechanisms.1,2 Cold gas propulsion is clearly the simplest and the most cost effective type of propulsion system; moreover, nowadays it is the best choice for attitude control of satellites.3–6 The capabilities such as fast response time, lower weight compared to the alternate small satellite propulsion systems, high accuracy in thrust magnitude, low power consumption, simple mechanism, acceptable reliability and nontoxic exhaust, which can affect sensors and actuators make these propulsion systems useful and common devices for spatial missions.7–9 Depending on the size of the satellite or probe, the orbit control is usually achieved by means of thrusters of 10 to 22 N and attitude control is performed with thrusters having thrust levels between 1 and 22 N. Although the cold gas propulsion systems are optimized for the low thrust level, several special cases are produced to provide more than 20 N thrust (e.g. Moog system 50-673, is designed for 44.5 N in vacuum10). The cold gas thruster consists of several major components in which the thermodynamic properties of the operating media change during the operating time. This implies that the process cannot be assumed as steady. All the components have operating limitations in pressure and temperature which should be considered through the design process. Mission requirements can further restrict the design of the cold gas propulsion system. These limitations include the total weight and volume of the system as well as the component weight, size and volume. A simple cold gas thruster consists of a tank containing pressurized gas, a set of thrusters discharging into ambient pressure and a group of different valves such as fill and drain, pressure regulator and latch valve as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Cold gas propulsion system.

In addition to the thrusters, for a real mission, there are other components consuming the operating media of the tank, both when the thrusters are active or in standby mode. The mass flow consumption scenario considered in this study is presented in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Mass consumption scenario.

The system parameters can be divided into two major parts in order to create a physical and mathematical model of the cold gas. First, constant parameters include thrust profile, number of thrusters, supplementary gas, subsidiary mass flow consumer and ambient operating condition. Second, design variables consist of type of the operating gas, tank charging pressure, nozzle inlet pressure and heat flux.

Due to variation of thermodynamic properties inside the tank during the process along with the system component transient response, the flow cannot be assumed steady. Makled et al.3 developed mathematical models to investigate steady-state and dynamic performance of the individual components. However, for pulses with long duration, i.e. 0.2 s, the effect of valve time constant is negligible. However, the fluid dynamic behavior is, nevertheless, considerable. Since the cold gas thruster is not a distinct and independent subsystem, it should be integrated with the other subsystems. To minimize the cost of the mission, one may state that it is necessary to decrease the mass of the operating media. However, the problem is that the mass of fluid cannot be reduced from a minimum value due to the required thrust and operational limitations. The pressure and temperature drop and their effects on system components as well as the maximum pressure for the design of the tank should be considered along with the mass and size of the system. Therefore, problems such as extensive range of thermodynamic variations, large number of variable parameters, complex scenario of mass consumption, operational limits for the system components along with the mission requirements make the analysis and optimization extremely complicated. The trade-off analysis helps to set the design parameters to appropriate values in order to satisfy the mission requirements with a minimum penalty.

sec.title: Design strategy
sec.p:
As a general modeling rule, in the current study, physical models of the components are translated into a set of differential equations (ODEs) which are solved repetitively to obtain the minimum requirements for the specified mission. The main part of this study discusses the sensitivity of the system components from the size, weight and performance point of view with respect to the design parameters. Sensitivity analysis is performed over intervals, containing design point, which is not precisely known and can be selected throughout the analysis cycle. After the sensitivity analysis, according to the best value of parameters, the system design will be carried out. However, the design strategy can be related to the type of the constraint which is imposed to the problem. In general, the problem breakdown structure can be considered as shown in Figure 3. If the arrangement is the main design constraint, the tank volume, which constitute the largest portion of the system, should be considered at the start of the optimization process. Initially, the volume of the tank is presumed as the whole system volume is known, though the physical constraint imposed by the satellite itself (Step 1). Although this volume may not be sufficient to provide the mission total impulse, it must be clarified during the design process. The counter, N, represents this issue. As the volume or mass is known, by applying the statistical data, an appropriate nozzle inlet pressure is selected by the designer (Step 2). Next, the inlet pressure is fixed and all the thermodynamic properties will be dynamically calculated (Step 4). If pressure and temperature of the gas, size and mass of the system components, which are calculated in the previous steps, do not approach appropriate values, the calculated data are regarded as unreasonable (Step 5). These parameters should guaranty the satisfaction of the mission requirements and off-the-shelf existence of such as well. Figure 3.
Design strategy for the cold gas propulsion system.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics.

The output of the calculation is the minimum weight of the gas, which is required to obtain the total impulse. In addition, the tank charging pressure will be determined. Since the minimum temperature and maximum pressure are the physical constraints on the elements, they determine the level of technology which is necessary for the system. By gathering a comprehensive database from different companies, the range of limitations is also accessible. The above cycle will also help to find appropriate intervals for the sensitivity analysis.

As well as the system volume, weight and tank charging pressure could also be taken to start the optimization process (Step 1). The type of initial constraint is totally based on the limitations that exist according to the mission requirements. In these scenarios, if the system weight or tank charging pressure is used instead of tank volume, step (3) will change in order to find the minimum tank volume.

After determining the analysis intervals, the sensitivity analysis is performed and the best values for the design variables will be selected (Step 6). The result of the sensitivity analysis will then be utilized to design an optimal system (Step 7). If appropriate values of the design variables are not approved for the predefined mission requirements, it is recommended to modify these requirements (Steps 6′ and 7′).

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p: A schematic layout of a cold gas propulsion system is presented in Figure 1. All the components can affect the thermodynamic properties of the gas along the high pressure passage to the nozzle. To develop the governing equations which can exactly describe the system behavior, a number of reasonable assumptions must be made. The major components are the tank, nozzle and pressure regulator. The other components slightly change the total pressure and temperature in this study. The response time of the valves is further assumed to be negligible. The speed of the gas in the nozzle is fast enough not to allow heat transfer from the walls of the nozzle. Thus the nozzle is assumed to be adiabatic. In general, the deviation of gas from ideal behavior becomes more significant for the low temperature or the high pressure due to molecular interactions. Compressibility factor of the gas is obtained by Lee-Kesler compressibility model.11 The amount of heat transfer to the tank and the other components at the upstream of pressure regulator is assumed to be constant and known. However, it can be a function of time. Moreover, it can be replaced by the heat flux which is applied to the system by electric heater.

Assuming constant thermodynamic properties inside the tank and using the above assumptions, the combination of continuity, momentum, energy and equation of state provides a set of equations representing the system thermodynamic behavior. Taking the tank and upstream components altogether as a control volume, the energy equation can be reduced as follows (1)T·t,t=m·tmg,t (Tt (γ-1 ) )+Q·mg,tR. The equation of state yields the following differential equation (2)P·t,t=ZPt,t (m·tmg,t+T·t,tTt,t ). In equation (2), Z represents the compressibility factor. The continuity equation can be obtained from the nozzle, which adjusts the fluid mass flow rate. (3)m·n=-CdA n,tPt,nTt,nγR (2γ+1 )γ+12 (γ-1 ) In the above equation, Cd is designated as the discharge coefficient of the nozzle, which depends on the Reynolds number in the throat of the nozzle and the negative sign is due to the fact that all equations are written according to parameter variation inside the tank. Massier12 established a correlation for the coefficient of discharge for supersonic nozzle as follows (4)Cd=0.8825+0.0079ln (Reth )

In addition to the thrusters, a subsidiary mass flow rate may be needed at the outlet of the regulator, which does not affect the regulator exit pressure, and is consumed by pneumatic actuators or other devices. With respect to this issue, the system leakage can further be considered as a subsidiary flow. Therefore, the continuity equation yields (5)m·t=m·n+m·leak+m·s

For the pressure regulators, the flow coefficient indicates the flow capabilities at a fully opened condition. Equation (6) is extracted from the TESCOM company database.13 Several references proposed similar formulas and entered the effect of temperature on flow coefficient.14 For more accuracy, Cv might be replaced by technical graphs for each of the utilized valve from the company catalog. (6)Cv= {2QgSgPi,reg;ifPi,reg>2Po,regQgSgPo,regΔPreg;ifPi,reg≤2Po,reg

The solenoids are supposed to be fully opened or fully closed and drop the pressure a little. For the other components, assuming no mass storage, the inlet and outlet pressure can be correlated with a coefficient of merit. This coefficient can be expressed in terms of temperature and pressure and the mass flow through the component as well. In this study, a constant gain is used to model the component.

Assuming that the flow is completely axial at the exit of the nozzle and the viscous effect is negligible in divergent part of nozzle due to large value of fluid speed, momentum equation could be applied to the nozzle. (7)Thrust=m·n (Ve,n-V0 )+Ae,n (Pe,n-Pa ) In this equation, V0 is assigned as the speed of vehicle and Pa is signified as the ambient pressure. It should be noted that viscous effects are further considered in the continuity equation.

sec.title: Element selection and design
sec.p: As previously stated in introduction, cold gas propulsion system consists of several major components which need to be designed or selected. Off-the-shelf design implies that several components such as fill and drain valve should carefully be selected according to operational requirements. In other words, selected elements should be well integrated with the other components of the system. Therefore, only storage tank and nozzle need to be optimally designed and pressure regulator, filter and solenoid valves need to be selected. Regulators and valves have traditionally been sized using equations derived by the company. Improper valve sizing can be costly and leads to the failure of the whole system. Low capacity valve will not pass the required flow, and the process will be starved. An oversized valve will be more expensive, and it can lead to instability of the system.13 Selecting the correct valve size for a cold gas propulsion system requires not only the feed line geometry, but also the knowledge of process conditions which the valve will actually see in operation. The most important issues which should be considered in selection and sizing of the components include pipeline size, fluid delivery capability, valve weight, valve size, the maximum and minimum operating pressure and temperature, response time, leakage, type of operating media, delivery error, operating cycle limit, price and availability. Since the current study does not intend to describe the overwhelming process of selection, the next sections focus on the design of the nozzle and the tank.

sec.title: Nozzle
sec.p: Thus, the design of the nozzle must trade-off between nozzle size, which is needed to obtain better performance against nozzle weight penalty and complexity of the shape for shock-free performance versus the cost of fabrication. The cold gas thrusters usually have a very small throat area. Besides, for nozzle expected to create higher pressure ratio, thus the length of the nozzle may increase significantly. Having small throat area, as the expansion ratio of the nozzle increases, CNC production machining can become too expensive. In order to increase the efficiency, the design of a shock-free nozzle is usually performed with the method of characteristics.15,16 In 1959, Rao17 formulated a direct optimization approach to maximize the performance for a prescribed bell type nozzle, based on the method of characteristics. Later, Rao18 simplified this design approach by showing that thrust optimized contours are highly similar to rather simple parabolic contours. This contour is utilized in the Vulcain 2 (used on the Ariane 5 launcher) and SSME (Space Shuttle Main Engine).19–21 (8)y=Ax+B+Cx+D

The profile of the whole nozzle is considered to include four segments composed of upstream parabolic interpolation, upstream arc, downstream arc, and downstream parabolic interpolation. Radius of each arc is a function of throat radius as presented in Figure 4. Applying the four constraints for each of the parabolic sections, constant factors, A to D, in equation (8) can be determined. These constrains are angles (α) and diameters (R) as shown in Figure 4. The angles can be found from the nozzle design text books.22,23 Figure 4.
Construction of the nozzle profile.

In addition, it is determined that if the nozzle expansion ratio is greater than 10, a three-degree polynomial can be replaced by the parabolic profile. It means that both profiles give the same contour. For low area ratio nozzles, the parabolic profile is better due to lower curvature and hence fewer losses. In the later sections the final 2D and 3D profiles for two sample case studies are presented for authentication.

sec.title: Storage tank
sec.p:
Storage tank is an important factor when designing a cold gas propulsion system. During the design of the tank the following issues should be considered.
– Design conditions and loadings.
– Weld joint efficiency.
– Reinforcement of openings.
– Flange and head design.
– Maximum allowable pressure. Loads that a tank may encounter are also as follows.
– Internal or external pressure.
– Superimposed static and dynamic reaction loads (e.g. launch impact).
– Cyclic and dynamic reactions which are caused by pressure or thermal variations, or by equipment mounted on the tank, as well as mechanical loadings.
– Temperature gradients within the tank and differential thermal expansion among the tank components.

The shape of the storage tank should be designed according to the layout of the system and the space which is assigned to the cold gas propulsion system. American Society of Mechanical Engineer (ASME) provides rules for the construction of pressure vessels. This includes requirements for materials, design, fabrication, examination, inspection and stamping. Assuming the spherical shape, ASME code uses the equation (9) to calculate the minimum required thickness for spherical pressure tank.24 (9)t=KrP2SE-0.2P In this equation, P is assigned as the maximum internal pressure which tank encounters in its life time, S is designated as the maximum allowable stress of the tank material, E represents the weld joint efficiency, K is denoted as the safety factor and r is labeled as the radius of the tank. Weld joint efficiency accounts for the quality of a welded joint and for the concentration of local stress. This higher local stress is due to the local material or structural discontinuities. It should be noted that the tank should be designed for a condition to maximize the thickness of the tank. Accordingly, the maximum pressure and temperature is used for design of the tank. The maximum internal pressure occurs when the temperature of the tank rises to its highest value, possibly during the charging process. Although ECSS standards propose safety factor of 1.0 for metallic and 1.15 for composite cases,24 a safety factor of 1.5 is considered to ensure a safe operation of the tank for both metallic and composite designs to account for uncertainties, thermal gradients, temperature changes and residual stresses.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p:
To choose the best values for the system parameters, sensitivity analysis is made according to Table 1. Table 1.
Strategy for sensitivity analysis.
Components Activator Disturbed parameter
Nozzle Operating media type, nozzle inlet pressure and design altitude (nozzle exit pressure) Length, inlet diameter, exit diameter, throat diameter, weight and expansion ratio
Heat addition Throat Reynolds, discharge coefficient
Tank Operating media type, nozzle inlet pressure, design altitude and heat addition Size and weight
Valves, regulator and filter Operating media type, nozzle inlet pressure and design altitude Minimum operating temperature, mass flow rate and flow coefficient

Tank operating temperature which is not mentioned in Table 1 is also important in some cases. Since it is a mission requirement, it is considered as a constant input parameter for sensitivity analysis.

As shown in Table 2, a sample case study is presented to prove the ability of the sensitivity analysis, which is described in the subsequent sections. Table 2.
Problem statement as a case study for sensitivity analysis.
Parameter Value Parameter Value
Thrust (N) 10 Number of active thrusters 2
Pulse duration (s) 0.2 Operating altitude (km) 65
Pulse delay (ms) 2 Final residual gas weight (kg) 2
Number of pulses 50 Subsidiary mass flow (g/s) 10
Tank material IM6/Epoxy Final temperature (K) 220
Nozzle material Steel/AlSI302 Heat transfer 0

To achieve this, a Matlab GUI code is developed to formulate and solve system of equations for the sensitivity analysis and optimization process. General layout of the program, which is called CGSA (cold gas sensitivity analysis), is shown in Figure 5. This code consists of three main parts including input data section, design strategy and output sections. The sensitivity analysis is performed according to Table 1 and the results are presented in the following sections. Figure 5.
Layout of the CGSA code.

sec.title: Operating media
sec.p:
Operating media is one of the most important parameters which have strong influences on the design of cold gas propulsion system. To select the operating media, the three criteria which were mentioned in previous section are used. Figure 6 illustrates the variation of design parameters versus tank charging pressure for different operating fluids. Primary axis of Figure 6 shows the required tank volume (RTV) for the specified mission. It displays that in order to use helium and hydrogen for the predefined mission, it does need extremely large storage tank. Secondary axis of Figure 6 indicates the net initial weight (NIW) including the tank, nozzle and the required gas. However, the components may change as the type of the gas changes individually; the corresponding effects are minor and do not change the result. Figure 6.
Comparison of net weight and required tank volume for different operating media.
NIW: net initial weight; RTV: required tank volume.

As the figure shows, the type of the fluid affects the weight of the system. Helium reduces the weight less than 20% with respect to oxygen and hydrogen. It must be noted that due to the dependency of the total weight to various parameters such as empty tank weight, if any input such as the subsidiary mass flow, final residual gas and thrust magnitude changes, the trend of the net weight with respect to different fluids may change as well. Another issue which should be considered is the type of material which is employed for the components. In this case, it is supposed that the material of the tank is made of composite epoxy. If the material changes to anything but the composite, the tank empty weight and the net initial weight increases extensively from nitrogen to hydrogen.

Using CGSA, the sensitivity analysis is further carried out to analyze other parameters as listed in Table 1. To save space, corresponding illustrations are discarded and only the main results are presented as follows.
– Using helium leads to lower expansion ratio nozzle with better axial flow distribution.
– Hydrogen increases specific impulse nearly 250% and helium increases it about 130% relative to nitrogen and oxygen.
– The best value of thrust coefficient is achieved by using helium.

Although helium and hydrogen create better flow quality and specific impulse, trade-off between their pros and cons makes them inappropriate choices for the specified mission. The higher required volume for helium and hydrogen usages leads to extremely higher weight for metallic tank usages. Though using hydrogen and helium provides remarkable higher specific impulse, the system is designed to deliver the same amount of thrust for all these fluids. In addition, leakage is an important issue for the cold gas propulsion systems. Helium and hydrogen have the risk of leakage more than the nitrogen and oxygen due to their molecular size. According to what was expressed, nitrogen and oxygen are the best options. Nitrogen is inert unlike the oxygen which makes it reliable and safe. Once the operating media is selected, the other sensitivity will only be performed on that fluid.

sec.title: Nozzle inlet pressure
sec.p:
Nozzle inlet pressure is a key factor because it affects the nozzle expansion ratio and discharge coefficient well as; moreover, it will affect throat diameter and tank initial weight. Figure 7(a) shows the discharge coefficient and nozzle throat diameter for different tank inlet pressure. The result reveals that for an inlet pressure higher than 2 bar, the thrust coefficient will improve gradually. This means that if nozzle inlet pressure is chosen in this interval, the efficiency of the nozzle will change very slowly. The net initial weigh and nozzle expansion ratio are shown in Figure 7(b). It shows that higher values of nozzle inlet pressure will decrease the weight of the system. As the nozzle inlet pressure increases, the exit and throat diameter and nozzle length will decrease. As the length of the nozzle decreases, the weight of the nozzle and hence the weight of the system will reduce. Another important parameter which may change losses in the nozzle is the expansion ratio. As the nozzle expansion ratio increases, losses will increase. Although as nozzle inlet pressure increases, the net weight of the system decreases, it does not affect the amount of required fluid and tank empty weight noticeably unlike the nozzle weight. Trade-off between the above results reveals that the best value for nozzle inlet pressure should be around 2 bar for the specified mission. This will not increase the size of the nozzle as the lower values do and will not increase expansion ratio as the higher values do. Figure 7.
Effect of the nozzle inlet pressure on: (a) discharge coefficient and (b) net weight and required tank volume.

sec.title: Tank charging pressure
sec.p:
The effect of the tank charging pressure on the weight of the system and the required tank volume is presented in Figure 8. It can be deduced that the net weight of the system will increase as the tank charging pressure increases. Although the weight of the empty tank increases as the charging pressure increases, the weight of required gas will decrease as well. The increment of the tank empty weight is more than the increment in the amount of required fluid and therefore the overall weight will increase as the charging pressure increases. Furthermore, Figure 8 shows that the required tank volume will decrease as the charging pressure increases and the value of 370 bar will optimize the size of the tank. Even though the volume will decrease by increasing the initial pressure, the regulator which is needed to adjust the pressure from 370 to 2 bar will be heavy and complex. Although using a multi-stage regulator will improve the accuracy of nozzle inlet pressure, it will certainly increase the weight of the system.2 Figure 8.
Effect of tank charging pressure on net weight and required tank volume.
To obtain the higher accuracy with lower weight and cost, the value of 300 bar is chosen for the tank charging pressure.

sec.title: Regulator flow coefficient
sec.p:
Figure 9 shows the regulator flow coefficient versus inlet pressure for different mass flow rates. Since the inlet pressure changes during the time over a wide range, the minimum value of this coefficient needs to be specified. In addition, the flow coefficient increases with increasing the mass flow rate which will change during the operation as well. Therefore, the maximum value of mass flow rate and the minimum value of inlet pressure determine the value characteristic and the flow coefficient. Due the temperature limitation as well as the regulator characteristics, the tank pressure will not roughly become lower than 100 bar. Since the maximum value of mass flow rate for the defined scenario is 35 g/s, the minimum regulator flow coefficient is determined to be 0.1. Figure 9.
Effect of mass flow rate on regulator flow coefficient for different inlet pressure.

sec.title: Heat inclusion
sec.p:
If the system operates continuously for a long time, the temperature of the compressed operating media will drop considerably. To prevent the intensive temperature drop, an electrical heater could be used to warm up the fluid during the thrusting. Figure 10 shows the required tank volume and the system net weight versus heat flux addition. Figure 10.
Effect of heat addition on tank volume and net weight.

For the aforementioned scenario, an average of 7 W energy can compensate the temperature drop due to the consumption of 1 g of the operating media. As a result, for the defined mission, the weight of the system will decrease about 10% due to the reduction of the required gas. On the other hand, it decreases the volume of the tank approximately 15% (about 2 L). It is concluded that an electronic heater which is less than 0.6 kg and produces 230 W continuous heat supply, seems practical for the current case study. The usefulness of the heat addition can be more evident if the mass consumption increases or the gas in the tank is consumed completely during the process. In this case for higher values of heat flux, temperature constraint will be satisfied during the process. In this condition, the fluid temperature will not fall below 220 K and this is why the trend remains constant after the 230 W point as illustrated in Figure 10. The capacity of the battery needed for this purpose can be calculated easily by W=PtCapacity:WV=Itt≅50×0.2=10sWV=10×2303600×11.2=0.057A.h(10) In the aforementioned equation, W is designated as the energy stored in the battery, t is assigned as the time, and V is signified as the voltage of the battery. Therefore, a battery with voltage of 11.2 V and capacity of 57 mAh will be sufficient to produce the required heat flux for the stated case study.

sec.title: Detail design
sec.p:
The results of the sensitivity analysis are utilized for the aforementioned scenario. In this section, the detail of integrated cold gas propulsion system which is optimally designed according to the trade-off sensitivity analysis is presented. The profiles of the nozzle, the shape of the tank, the weight of the system components and variation of temperature, pressure, mass flow and specific impulse during the time are clearly specified. The overall results are illustrated in Table 3. The nozzle profile is further shown in Figure 13(b). Table 3.
Optimized design parameters.
Parameter Value Parameter Value
Nozzle inlet diameter (mm) 18.06 Tank charging pressure (bar) 300
Nozzle throat diameter (mm) 6.01 Nozzle length (diverging part, mm) 161
Nozzle exit diameter (mm) 107 Average specific impulse (s) 67.61
Minimum tank volume (L) 7.61 Regulator average mass flow (g/s) 34.2
Tank spherical diameter (mm) 244 Nozzle exit Mach number 8.93
Initial operating gas weight (kg) 3.34 Minimum connection diameter (mm) 15.24

According to the results, the variation of parameters versus time is presented in Figure 11. As shown in the figure, even though temperature, pressure and specific impulse decrease, the mass flow rate increases to compensate the effect of temperature drop. It makes the thrust nearly unchanged during the process. However, the temperature variation, changes the Reynolds of the throat and it will slightly change the thrust. Figure 11.
Variation of parameters during the thrusting.

sec.title: Experimental setup and validation
sec.p:
Since the real cold gas thrusters usually operate in a very low ambient pressure, in order to create a realistic test environment, a high capacity vacuum system is required, as well as exclusive tools to reduce model uncertainties which make the whole setup prohibitively expensive. Therefore, a test setup is designed with an ambient discharge pressure not only to determine the magnitude and accuracy of thrust, mass flow rate, temperature and pressure variations during the process, but also to validate the analytical simulation and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis. As shown in Figure 12, due to a large discharge pressure, the size of the nozzle is too small. Therefore, the nozzle inlet pressure is adjusted to 15 bar absolute and the system is designed to deliver 20 N of thrust. The final specifications of the corresponding nozzle are listed in Table 4. The nozzle profile is shown in Figure 13(a). Nitrogen is used as an operating media which is stored in a tank with volume of 70 L. As shown in Figure 14, the magnitude of thrust is measured using a beam-type load cell. The output voltage of the load cell is calibrated and stored by data acquisition system after amplification Figure 12.
Ground-mounted nozzle.
Figure 13.
Nozzle profile for: (a) ground-mounted and (b) spatial nozzle.
Figure 14.
Ground-mounted: (a) test stand and (b) system setup.
Table 4.
Specifications of ground-mounted thruster.
Parameter Value
Divergent part length (mm) 3.2
Inlet diameter (mm) 4.29
Throat diameters (mm) 3.58
Nozzle exit diameter (mm) 5.6
Expansion ratio 1.92
Exit Mach number 2.41
Average Isp (s) 56
Thrusting time (s) 4.55
Average mass flow (g/s) 34

The graphical environment which is developed using the LabView software assists us to view and manipulate the desired quantities such as thrust, temperature and pressure. As shown in Figure 14, the thruster can move back and push the load cell along the nozzle axis. Furthermore, four other sensors are further employed to measure the thermodynamic properties of the operating media.

Figure 15 shows the actuation response of the system to a pulse excitation lasting 4.55 s. For the aforementioned scenario, the accuracy is found to be higher than 96.5% with respect to the desired thrust magnitude. In addition, it shows that the trend of variation of pressure through the pulse time is in consonant with the analytical simulation. Figure 15.
Parameter variation during the test and comparison with analytical simulation.

Equation of state helps to roughly estimate the average value of mass flow rate during the thrusting time. In order to obtain this, the initial state of P1 = 164.8 bar, T1 = 300 and Z1 = 1.0342 as well as the final state of P2 = 159.7 bar, T2 = 296 and Z2 = 1.0288 for the compressed fluid inside the tank during the 4.55 s thrusting time are obtained. Discretizing the equation of state and substituting the initial and final state parameters yields PV=ZmRT⇒m·≅ΔmΔt=m1Δt (ΔPP1-ΔTT1-ΔZZ1 )=34g/s Comparison of analytical simulation with the experimentally estimated value validates the accuracy of the results.

sec.title: CFD analysis of spatial nozzle
sec.p:
CFD simulation has often been regarded as a tool for the solution of problems which cannot be solved using classical analytical methods. It is an efficient method to explore and predict the fluid flow behavior. In the current study, this tool is utilized to validate the results of the CGSA code as well as to check the experimental setup. Hence, a method which is based on the finite volume technique in order to solve the Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes equations was selected to compute and predict the flow pattern inside the nozzle. Axisymmetric non-recirculating exhaust structures are computed efficiently from time-averaged Navier–Stokes equations by means of marching algorithm.25 Within the divergent part of the nozzle, the dynamic of high-speed fluid makes the effect of boundary layer negligible. Here, as shown in Figure 16(a), a hybrid structured–unstructured computational grid with 87,000 computational cells for nozzle and 300,000 cells for control volume was built to capture the boundary layer with minimum computational error. The upstream boundary condition was set to ‘pressure inlet’, nozzle outlet to ‘interior’ and surrounding edges to ‘pressure far field’. False diffusion, which arises from the numerical approximations of the convection terms is one of the most important issues that should be considered in numerical solutions of the Navier–Stokes equations.26,27 Several methods are implemented to address this issue. Using higher order discretization, aligning the grid with the flow direction and increasing the number of grid cells are the few to name. Density-based scheme with second-order upwind discretization for convective flux and ‘Spalart-Allmaras’ model with second-order discretization is employed for viscous flux computation. A PC Core 2 Duo, CPU 2.5 GHz and 4GB RAM was employed in simulation. The CPU time was calculated about 2 h for each case. Figure 16.
CFD simulation: (a) 2D nozzle mesh before revolving, (b) variation of Mach number in spatial nozzle, (c) shock formation inside the nozzle for outlet pressure of 1500 Pa and (d) contours of static temperature for ground-mounted nozzle.

The CFD analysis returned a thrust of 9.36 N for spatial thruster and 19.24 N for ground-mounted thruster. This means that the relative error of thrust is less than 7% for both spatial and ground-mounted nozzle. As the nozzle inlet pressure increases from the design value, the flow in the nozzle will be over-expanded. If the nozzle inlet pressure decreases, flow will be under-expanded as well. The grid dependency is also checked for different schemes and mesh sizes. The results revealed that the thrust magnitude changes were well within an acceptable margin of 0.5%.

When the nozzle inlet pressure becomes less than a specific value, a shock forms in the divergent part and moves from the nozzle outlet to the throat as the input pressure decreases and finally the flow becomes subsonic in the nozzle. In addition, if the nozzle back pressure increases, a shock can occur in divergent part of the nozzle For example if the back pressure increases to 1500 Pa, shock formation is shown in Figure 16(c). The temperature variation and the flow pattern is shown in Figure 16(b) and (d) for both cases in normal expansion condition.

In order to compare the result of the analytical simulation with the CFD results, flow properties on the nozzle centerline are picked. The values for static pressure are presented in Figure 17(a) for spatial nozzle and 17(b) for ground-mounted nozzle. The results are in a highly reasonable agreement especially for inlet and outlet part of the nozzle. The minor differences are due to the effects of viscous dissipation and three-dimensional flow effects. Figure 17.
Comparison of CFD and CGSA code results from aspect of static pressure in centerline of the nozzle for: (a) spatial nozzle and (b) ground-mounted nozzle.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics; CGSA: cold gas sensitivity analysis.

sec.title: Conclusion and closing remarks
sec.p: The optimal design of an integrated cold gas thruster system which takes all effective elements into account along with mass consumption scenario makes this study novel and represents a valuable contribution in this field. Designers usually encounter numerous variable parameters when designing a cold gas propulsion system. The constraints as well as the design strategy will assist us to choose the most appropriate design parameters. In order to design an optimal system, three criteria, namely, minimum weight, minimum volume and the best performance are determined to calculate the variable parameters. Since the design variables usually exhibit contradictory behaviors, the trade-off analysis is employed for the optimization process. Considering all the design variables, a numerical code is developed, based on quasi-one-dimensional analysis to help design, development and implementation of an optimal system. With respect to this issue, the design variables are selected in accordance with the mission requirements. It is further presumed that the thrust magnitude and profile are known and the cold gas thruster is a distinct system. It is shown that by using an electric heater, the volume of the tank and the net initial weight will be greatly reduced. Furthermore, it avoids rapid drop in the gas temperature which helps the components of the system work properly. It is shown that the thrust magnitude will not considerably change during the system operation. In order to validate the analytical results, as well as the CFD simulation, an experimental setup is designed and the system is examined for the specific test case. The presented results demonstrate a great agreement between analytical predictions, the CFD simulation and the experimental outcomes.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank H. Kashani and N. Afsa for making valuable contribution to this research and for their supportive comments and suggestions.
